headline.print_headline: Westin Creates Six Pillars of Well-Being in a Program for Guests and Employees
headline.main: Westin Creates Six Pillars of Well-Being in a Program for Guests and Employees

docs.abstract: Advertising column; new well-being initiative by Westin Hotels will target not only guests but employees; similar initiatives have been very successful for chain in the past.
docs.lead_paragraph: The program is being introduced on Thursday to coincide with the International Day of Happiness, which promotes well-being, among other things, and the first day of spring.
docs.snippet: The program is being introduced on Thursday to coincide with the International Day of Happiness, which promotes well-being, among other things, and the first day of spring....

headline.seo: Hotel Review: Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom, in Vienna
headline.main: Hotel Review: Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom, in Vienna

docs.abstract: Sarah Wildman reviews Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom hotel in Vienna, Austria.
docs.lead_paragraph: The year-old Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom, designed by Jean Nouvel, offers a glamorous alternative to the Ringstrasse-based five stars and two-star pensions.
docs.snippet: The year-old Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom, designed by Jean Nouvel, offers a glamorous alternative to the Ringstrasse-based five stars and two-star pensions....

headline.main: Business People; Running the Company Is So Much Easier

docs.lead_paragraph: He may know how to run a major hotel company, but Jonathan Tisch, the chief executive of Loews Hotels, cannot make an omelet worth a darn. Mr. Tisch will be in the first installment of ''Now Who's Boss,'' a reality series from TLC, the cable channel, in which chief executives are catapulted back to the front lines of their industries to gain an appreciation for the rank-and-file worker. For his episode, to be shown on March 8 at 10 p.m., Eastern time, Mr. Tisch spent five days working at the Loews Miami Beach hotel in a variety of jobs, including chambermaid, banquet server, engineer, pool attendant, bellman and front-desk clerk.

headline.main: A French Hotel For the Nation's Capital

docs.abstract: French hotel chain Sofitel opens new luxury hotel in Washington DC (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: That Sofitel, the French chain, should install one of its new luxury hotels in Washington seems only fitting. With its Parisian layout, its cafes and public squares, the city has more than a soupçon of French flavor. The hotel, with 220 rooms and 17 suites, is at 15th and H Streets NW, near Lafayette Square. It is a complete conversion of the historic Shoreham Building from the 1920's, first a hotel, then an office building. While architectural details like bas-relief sculptures and bronze panels have been restored on the limestone facade, a decidedly French air prevails inside. The designer Pierre-Yves Rochon has brought a 1930's Art Moderne feel to rooms and public spaces, with dark green marble, jewel tones, polished mahogany paneling and chrome details.

docs.abstract: Workers who lost their jobs when Marriott World Trade Center hotel was destroyed in terrorist attack of Sept 11 gather in Times Square to protest what they call company's broken promises to find them replacement jobs; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Workers who lost their jobs when Marriott World Trade Center hotel was destroyed in terrorist attack of Sept 11 gather in Times Square to protest what they call company's broken promises to find them replacement jobs; photo (S)...

docs.lead_paragraph: LONG a desirable residential neighborhood, Murray Hill, the East Side enclave of low-rise structures and shady streets between 34th and 42d Streets, is emerging as a vital commercial district as its office buildings, restaurants and hotels are upgraded by owners seeking to capitalize on its proximity to midtown. Among the owners pumping money into properties in that section is Doral Hotels Inc. In the last few years the company has gradually refurbished its three Murray Hill hotels: the Doral Tuscany at 120 East 39th Street off Park Avenue, the Doral Park Avenue at Park Avenue and 38th Street and the Doral Towers at 39th and Lexington Avenue. Doral is held by Carol Management, which has apartment and office buildings in the city, A $10 million renovation of the Doral Towers, currently under way, makes it the company's most ambitious project. Built in 1927 as the Peter Cooper Hotel, it evolved over the years into a mainly residential hotel. When Doral took over the somewhat shabby property in the 1960's, it planned to upgrade it and gradually make it a totally transient hotel again. It finally made the financial commitment about two years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "Shifting Rates of Hotel Rooms" by Suzanne Carmichael (Dec. 10) brought to mind a recent incident. Annually, for almost 20 years, I have stayed four or five days at the Breidenbacher Hof in Dusseldorf, now part of the Rafael chain. In May, I sent a fax requesting a double room for four nights beginning June 2, adding that I looked forward to returning to the hotel. I received a faxed confirmation quoting a daily rate of 520 German marks -- $385 at the time, with the mark at 1.35 to the dollar -- "instead of 610" with a notation that the hotel looked forward to welcoming me again. During a telephone conversation with a friend in Dusseldorf that day, I mentioned the quoted prices. He agreed that they sounded high and said he would call the hotel to verify the rates. He called back to say that the rate quoted to him was 440 marks a night with a weekend special rate of 310. He also faxed me a letter confirming the lower rates from the very same person who had quoted the higher rates to me.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I enjoyed Margo Kaufman's article "Bells and Whistles in the Bathroom" (Dec. 10) about the range and creativity of bathroom amenities. I think one of our recent experiences tops hers. In Zurich, we found in our charming bathroom basket of soap, shampoo, bubble bath, shower cap, etc. -- a supply of condoms! Now, that's what I call thoughtful. GLORIA CHARNY Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
